body:
@glenn-jocher  I understand whay you mean, but still I think it should be normalized at the very first input of the network. It is true that batch normalization does normalize your batches after the convolutional layers, but what I guess it might be happening is that since you are not normalizing your input, your biases is correcting the displacement w.r.t the pretrained model. Somehow you are making harder the training to your network, although the loss decreases and your detections are working fine. 

I will try different experiments with normalization and give you any feedback with this issuse!

@dbarrejon more research is always appreciated, though we already went down this path for the xview competition (https://github.com/ultralytics/xview-yolov3) last year, and did not see any performance improvement when normalizing input images during training. The relevant code is here:

https://github.com/ultralytics/xview-yolov3/blob/master/utils/datasets.py#L260
```python
# Normalize
img_all = np.stack(img_all)[:, :, :, ::-1].transpose(0, 3, 1, 2)  # BGR to RGB and cv2 to pytorch
img_all = np.ascontiguousarray(img_all, dtype=np.float32)
img_all -= self.rgb_mean
img_all /= self.rgb_std
```

What we do need help with however is hyperparameter evolution. If you have computational resources available to you there is a simple script you can run to help genetically evolve the existing hyperparameters to better train on COCO.

@glenn-jocher I find that you have removed the image normalization in the latest code. Is it for the use of Mosaic augmentation or something else? Can I use both Mosaic augmentation and image normalization at the same time? I want to test it for a custom dataset and see whether it lead to an increase of the mAP.
@ChrisLiiiii normalizing an image and what you do with it afterward are unrelated. Sure, feel free to experiment.

@glenn-jocher I would have several questions:

- If I happen to deploy a network on hardware, which requires mean = 0 and std_dev = 128 for each image dim s.t. out_im = (in_im - mean)/std_dev, how should I train the network? I am a bit confused: I have a pre-trained backbone network which was trained on Imagenet, and input images were pre-processed by subtracting the mean and dividing by the std_dev. 
Then, the actual detector is trained on another dataset by considering again the same kind of preprocessing, i.e. by subtracting from the input images the mean and diving by the std_dev of the new dataset. This should be correct in terms of matching. Yet, at the time of inference, how should I preprocess the input image?

- Do you mean that if the network supports batch normalization you don't need to pre-process the input images as aforementioned? And why YOLO is nevertheless doing a scaling by a factor 255?

- Basically, I would need the input images to be in the range [0,2] for deployment, thus 0 mean and std_dev = 128 for each channel. I have batch normalization in my backbone network. How should I behave according to you?

Sorry but I am a bit of inexperienced

Thank you!

@alex96295 255 is unrelated, this is int to float.

Deployment related issues to custom hardware we'd be happy to discuss under contract.
